attributes.value: / Pure Rust implementation of Ry큰, an algorithm to quickly convert floating
/ The PLDI'18 paper [*Ry큰: fast float-to-string conversion*][paper] by Ulf
/ Adams includes a complete correctness proof of the algorithm. The paper is
/ available under the creative commons CC-BY-SA license.
/ This Rust implementation is a line-by-line port of Ulf Adams' implementation
/ You can run upstream's benchmarks with:
/ And the same benchmark against our implementation with:
/ These benchmarks measure the average time to print a 32-bit float and average
/ time to print a 64-bit float, where the inputs are distributed as uniform random
/ The upstream C code, the unsafe direct Rust port, and the safe pretty Rust API
/ all perform the same, taking around 21 nanoseconds to format a 32-bit float and
/ There is also a Rust-specific benchmark comparing this implementation to the
/ standard library which you can run with:
/ The benchmark shows Ry큰 approximately 2-5x faster than the standard library
/ across a range of f32 and f64 inputs. Measurements are in nanoseconds per
/ This library tends to produce more human-readable output than the standard
/ library's to\_string, which never uses scientific notation. Here are two
/ Both libraries print short decimals such as 0.0000123 without scientific

allow(clippy :: cast_lossless, clippy :: cast_possible_truncation, clippy ::
        cast_possible_wrap, clippy :: cast_sign_loss, clippy ::
        checked_conversions, clippy :: doc_markdown, clippy ::
        expl_impl_clone_on_copy, clippy :: if_not_else, clippy ::
        many_single_char_names, clippy :: missing_panics_doc, clippy ::
        module_name_repetitions, clippy :: must_use_candidate, clippy ::
        similar_names, clippy :: too_many_lines, clippy :: unreadable_literal,
        clippy :: unseparated_literal_suffix, clippy :: wildcard_imports)

This is a cheap operation; you don't need to worry about reusing buffers
 for efficiency.

defs.docs:
Print a floating point number into this buffer and return a reference to
 its string representation within the buffer.

attributes.value: / Print a floating point number into this buffer and return a reference to
/ its string representation within the buffer.
/ This function formats NaN as the string "NaN", positive infinity as
/ "inf", and negative infinity as "-inf" to match std::fmt.
/ If your input is known to be finite, you may get better performance by
/ calling the `format_finite` method instead of `format` to avoid the

defs.name: format_finite
defs.value: pub fn format_finite<F: Float>(&mut Self, F) -> &str
defs.docs:
Print a floating point number into this buffer and return a reference to
 its string representation within the buffer.

attributes.value: / Print a floating point number into this buffer and return a reference to
/ its string representation within the buffer.
/ This function **does not** check for NaN or infinity. If the input
/ number is not a finite float, the printed representation will be some
/ correctly formatted but unspecified numerical value.
/ Please check [`is_finite`] yourself before calling this function, or
/ check [`is_nan`] and [`is_infinite`] and handle those cases yourself.

defs.name: Float
defs.docs:
A floating point number, f32 or f64, that can be written into a
 [`ryu::Buffer`][Buffer].

defs.name: format64
defs.value: pub unsafe fn format64(f64, *mut u8) -> usize
defs.docs: Print f64 to the given buffer and return number of bytes written.

attributes.value: / Print f64 to the given buffer and return number of bytes written.
/ At most 24 bytes will be written.
/ This function **does not** check for NaN or infinity. If the input
/ number is not a finite float, the printed representation will be some
/ correctly formatted but unspecified numerical value.
/ Please check [`is_finite`] yourself before calling this function, or
/ check [`is_nan`] and [`is_infinite`] and handle those cases yourself.
/ The `result` pointer argument must point to sufficiently many writable bytes
/     let len = ryu::raw::format64(f, buffer.as_mut_ptr() as *mut u8);
/     let slice = slice::from_raw_parts(buffer.as_ptr() as *const u8, len);

defs.name: format32
defs.value: pub unsafe fn format32(f32, *mut u8) -> usize
defs.docs: Print f32 to the given buffer and return number of bytes written.

attributes.value: / Print f32 to the given buffer and return number of bytes written.
/ At most 16 bytes will be written.
/ This function **does not** check for NaN or infinity. If the input
/ number is not a finite float, the printed representation will be some
/ correctly formatted but unspecified numerical value.
/ Please check [`is_finite`] yourself before calling this function, or
/ check [`is_nan`] and [`is_infinite`] and handle those cases yourself.
/ The `result` pointer argument must point to sufficiently many writable bytes
/     let len = ryu::raw::format32(f, buffer.as_mut_ptr() as *mut u8);
/     let slice = slice::from_raw_parts(buffer.as_ptr() as *const u8, len);
